abstract.p: With the frequent outbreak of influenza virus in urban areas, the ecological security of high-density housing is becoming increasingly prominent. An Eulerian-Lagrangian pollutant diffusion model based on Large Eddy Simulation (LES) is established to simulate the transport of airborne virus. After the reliability of the numerical model is validated by the indoor experiment, the indoor and outdoor dispersion of microbial aerosol are simulated. The exposure risk is further studied based on the space-time concentration of pathogenic microorganisms of numerical simulation. The outcome can provide evidences for building plan optimization, environmental risk analysis and safety withdrawal planning.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the rapidly increased density of urban population, the airborne disease pathogens infecting human by respiration are becoming a new challenge. In addition, the urban areas are also more dangerous to be a target of biological terror nowadays. Since some kinds of pathogens can be transmitted to tens of kilometres or even hundreds of kilometres in the state of aerosol [1], the investigation of the transportation mechanism of airborne disease pathogens and the strategy for prevention are becoming very important. Many scholars studied indoor air quality [2–6] and the infection of human health by microbial pollutants [7,8]. Some scholars carried out the research on the transportation of airborne disease pathogen [9]. However, most of these studies are small-scale experimental research and very few include numerical simulation approach.

Donaldson and Alexandersen [10] studied the dispersion of pathogen by Gauss plume dispersion model. Yu et al. [11] simulated airborne SARS pathogen in a building group. Liu and You [12] considered the transportation of disease pathogen with time-independent virus source. Gao et al. [13] applied Eulerian and Lagrangian approaches to investigate the dispersion of expiratory aerosols between two vertically adjacent ﬂats. At present, the study of transportation of airborne disease pathogen from indoor to outdoor is still lacking.

Risk is the probability of occurrence of potential accidents. Risk assessment includes hazard identified, dose-response relationship assessment, exposure assessment and risk characterization. As a major step in risk assessment, exposure assessment plays a vital role. It is widely used in epidemiological investigations, risk assessment and other studies. Zhu et al. [14] proposed an evaluation model of exposure risk analysis in a building group based on the numerical space-time concentration of pathogenic microorganisms.

In this paper, the movement of pathogen is considered by Eulerian-Lagrangian model in order to consider the velocity difference between the pathogen and air. The exposure assessment model of influenza virus is established by using the results of the Eulerian-Lagrangian model. The exposure assessment and safety area for the resident stay is obtained by considering the criterion of accumulated concentration of contaminants.

sec.title: Equations
sec.p: Eulerian-Lagrangian model is adopted in this approach [15]. For an incompressible fluid, the governing equations of continuous phase are derived from N-S equations. Considering the dispersed particles, a volume-averaged technique is used in the equations of mass and momentum conservation. The equations, Equations (1) and (2), for incompressible continuous phase take the following form: (1)∂ɛl∂t+∇·(ɛlu→l)=0 (1) (2)ρl∂(ɛl)∂t+ρl∇·(ɛl)=-∇p+∇·[μlɛl(∇+á∇lñT)]+ɛlρl+ (2) where, εl, u→l, ρl and μ are volume fraction, velocity, density and viscosity of continuous liquid phase, respectively. g→ is gravity acceleration. F→ is the body force acting on the continuous phase and the particles. T means transpose of a matrix.

LES approaches decompose the flow into large- and small-scale structures: the filtered large eddies are solved directly in a three-dimensional time-dependent fashion, while the small eddies are modelled. The Smagorinsky-Lilly model is used to determine turbulent viscosity for its simplicity and low computational cost. The LES equations and model parameters are described in reference [16].

The Lagrangian model is used to calculate the path of each individual particle. The motion of individual particles is determined by Newton’s second law of motion as given by Equation (3). (3)du→pdt=F→+g→ρp-ρlρp (3) where, F→ can be described by Equation (4) as: (4)F→=FD(u→l-u→p)+ρl2ρpddt(u→l-u→p)+F→A (4) where, u→p and ρp are the velocity and density of dispersed drops. FD and FA are drag force and additional force, respectively.

When the discrete and continuous phases are being coupled, it is better to apply an under-relaxation scheme to the momentum exchange terms for improving the numerical stability of the coupled calculation procedure given by Equation (5): (5)F→new=F→old+α(F→calculated-F→old) (5) where F→new is the momentum exchange term, F→old is the previous value, F→calculated is the newly computed value and α is the under-relaxation factor. Here α = 0.35 is adopted. Note that the value of α does not influence the predictions obtained in the final converged solution.
The calculation detail of particle moving path, the couple of discrete and continuous phases and the model parameters can be found in references [17–19].

sec.title: Exposure assessment
sec.p: The human exposure can be assessed by the concentration of microbial contamination given by Eulerian-Lagrangian model. The criteria of exposure assessment are described as the accumulated concentration of microbial contaminants.

Exposure refers to the human body staying in the environment of pollutant concentration during a certain period. The total body exposure to certain pollutants is known as exposure quantity. Exposure quantity can be divided into the potential exposure quantity, applicable exposure quantity and internal exposure quantity.

In terms of air pollutants, the potential exposure quantity refers to the human body inhaling the amount of contamination in a certain time. Applicable exposure quantity is the amount of contamination absorbed by respiratory system. Internal exposure quantity is the amount of contamination absorbed and entered the body by physical or biological processes. Generally speaking, the potential exposure quantity is applied more conveniently because the applicable exposure and internal exposure quantity are difficult to determine in the actual exposure assessment process.

The potential exposure quantity is [20]: (6)Cpot=∫tB tEc(t)IR(t)dt (6) where Cpot is the potential exposure quantity, IR(t) is respiratory rate per time, tB and tE are the beginning and end time of person suffering microbial infection, respectively. The concentration of pollutant c(t) is the total mass of pathogen particles per unit volume.

According to the exposure assessment, the microbial infection refers to a certain extent of pollutants accumulated inside the body. There are two main parameters in Equation (6). One is the concentration of microbial contaminant and the other is the respiration rate per time of the body. The average respiratory rate per time of person body IR(t) is determined by Equation (7). (7)IR(t)=∑iIRiti (7) where, IRi is the average respiratory rate of person in ith activity, ti is the ratio of ith activity time to that of total activity. The average respiration rate per time of adult and child is chosen as 1.222 and 0.955, respectively. The accumulated concentration ∫tB tEc(t)dt is the integral dose of virus for person staying in the microbial contaminant field from time tB to tE. It is a key value to be determined.

The potential exposure quantity criterion is used to evaluate the microbial pollution risks by the accumulated concentration. The accumulated concentration criterion is also interpreted as the maximum time of people staying in a certain contaminated field without being infected.

The retention capacity of microbial contamination R is introduced to consider the effect of building group on the transportation of microbial contamination. R is determined by Equation (8), as the ratio of the microbial biomass of building groups and emissions. (8)R=c¯V∫t1 t2Qdt (8) where, c¯ is the average concentration of microbial pollutants within the building groups, kg/m3. V is the volume of the computational domain, m3. Q is the emission rate of microbial pollutant source to outdoor, kg/s. R is an important parameter to consider how good the building layout is for pollutant transportation.

sec.title: Model Verification
sec.p: The reliability of the model was verified by the experimental data of Lu et al. [21]. The case of virus outbreak in a zone and diffusion in the whole room was simulated. LES model was used to deal with the turbulence of continuous phase. Lagrangian method was employed in tracking the particles and predicting the diffusion and concentration of pollutant. Finite volume method was used to discretise the model equations. Central difference scheme was introduced to approximate the convection phase of control volume. The couple of pressure-velocity was treated by SIMPLE algorithm.

sec.title: Problem Description
sec.p:
An office environment was simulated. A two-zone room shown in Figure 1 with a size of length × height × width = 5 × 2.4 × 3 m3 was used, which has the same geometrical configuration as the one used in experiments [21–23]. The room was divided into two zones by a partition with the door size of height × width = 0.95 × 0.7 m2. The partition was in the middle of the room length. The inlet and outlet were of the same size with the following dimensions: 0.15 × 0.5 × 1.0 m3. The inlet section was 1.6 m high from the ground and 1.5 m away from the front wall. The outlet section was 0.3 m high from the ground and 0.5 m away from the front wall. Based on experimental conditions, the ventilation rate was selected at 0.1026 m3/s. The room was divided into 63 × 38 × 30 cells in the direction of length, width and height. Fig. 1.
Geometrical configuration of room A1.

The discrete particles were considered as spherical solid particles. The particles were assumed to be uniformly distributed with the size range l-5 µm. The density of particle was 865 kg/m3. Stochastic tracking was used to track particle turbulent diffusion. The numerical average particle concentration (µg/m3) in each zone was defined by Equation (9): (9)C=totalmassofsuspendedparticlesvolumeofeachzone (9)

sec.title: Results and Analysis
sec.p:
According to the particle tracking data, the particles in each zone at each tracking minute would be obtained. Comparisons of average particle concentrations in both zones between our computation and the experiments are presented in Figure 2. Fig. 2.
The particle concentration of zones 1 and 2.

The simulation and experiment were quite satisfactory for the case of boundary 1. A slight discrepancy between the model and experimental results was shown. The experimental data were generally higher than the computational results. For the case of boundary 2, the results of simulation were much lower than those of experiment.

The above results indicate that the collision boundary setting is critical to predict the average concentration of particles in the room. If all surface boundaries are assumed to be rebound, trap or deposit boundary, the concentration of indoor particles would not be predicted accurately. If the suitable boundary conditions for particles are chosen, such as the boundary 1 in our case, the reasonable concentration of indoor particles is predicted.

sec.title: Modelling Details
sec.p:
For studying the microbial aerosol transportation from indoor to outdoor, the arrangement of buildings and wind direction are shown in Figure 3. The length and width of all buildings were H = 15m. The height was 4 H. The distance between the front and back building columns was H. The distance between the two buildings in a column was H. Fig. 3.
The arrangement of virus outbreak room A1 and buildings group.

The above two-zone testing room shown in Figure 1 was situated in building A. The room (zone 2) outlet was a window connected to outdoor. The microbial aerosol was dispersed from the indoor to outdoor through the window.

The case considered here was that the outbreak of virus happened firstly in the room zone 1, and then the virus spread to the room zone 1, and finally outdoor through the window. The dispersion of microbial aerosol from indoor to outdoor was studied.
After numerical tests, the domain −200 m ≤ x 800 m, −215 m ≤ y ≤ 215 m 0 ≤ z ≤ 180 m with the ground front centre of buildings A located at (0,0,0) was suitable for the present approach.

For outdoor continuous phase air, the inlet and outlet were the inlet velocity and outflow boundary, respectively. At inlet boundary, the wind speed was: u = uref(z/href)0.25 m/s and the pathogen concentration was c = 0. The reference velocity uref and height href were 5 m/s and 60 m, respectively. At the outflow boundary, the velocity was assumed to be fully developed. At the outdoor side and top boundaries, the velocity was controlled by symmetric boundary conditions. The non-slip boundary was applied at all walls of buildings and ground. The initial condition was free of pathogen in the computational domain.

For outdoor discrete phase microbial aerosol (particles), the boundary conditions at the inflow, outflow, side and top boundaries were escape boundary. The boundary conditions at the building walls were rebound boundary and the boundary condition at ground was trap boundary.

sec.title: Results and Analysis
sec.p: After the converged flow field of continuous phase was established, 210,000 particles were distributed uniformly in zone 1 as the initial condition. With the increase of time, the virus spread firstly to zone 2 (The window of zone 2 locates at wall d) and then transmitted to outdoor through the window (outlet).

Figure 4 shows the indoor particle distribution with different time. The spreading process of virus particle from zone 1 to zone 2 and finally exiting to outdoors is clearly shown. One dot represents one particle in Figure 4. The outdoor airflow vector field at t = 200 s is shown in Figure 5. Fig. 4.
Indoor particle distribution at different time. Fig. 5.
Airflow vector field at t = 200 s with the height z = 3/5H.

The streaklines (areas) are dense particles areas, which represent the high concentration of particles. In these areas, the effects of convection would be much higher than those of dispersion. Thus, the streaklines (areas) represent the initial high concentration particles following the wind velocity which transport the particles between the buildings.

The stability test of aerosol concentration has been conducted in a similar approach as given by references [23,24]. The results indicate that the concentration C = 10cfu/VB was large enough to neglect the stochastic property of particles.

sec.title: Infective Evaluation
sec.p:
In order to evaluate the infective effects of the virus on the residents in building A, the accumulated concentration on four outdoor walls was calculated. Figure 7 shows the accumulated concentration at the walls of building A. Fig. 7.
Flu virus accumulated concentration at the walls of building A (6 ≤ z ≤ 9 m) with respect to time.

The virus concentration in the concerned room was not the same as that of outdoor region close to the wall because of the existence of concentration gradients. However, the virus concentration in the outside would be used to represent that in the adjacent room for simplicity. Thus, the accumulated concentration of virus in the concerned room could be assumed to be the same as that of outdoor wall if the room window was opened. Thus, the indoor accumulated concentration was determined using the concentration on the outdoor wall without loss in generality.

From Figure 7, the accumulated concentration would be highest at wall d. The higher accumulated concentration in wall d was related to the opening window of room A1 on wall d and the low wind velocity closed to wall d. Figure 6 clearly indicates that there was a high concentration area on wall d. This would mean that the room near wall d was more dangerous than that close to other walls. The person would therefore be infected easily for the same staying time at the room near wall d. If the concentration of the virus was less than the criterion of instantaneous infective concentration, the safety time for the person staying in a virus polluted room would be determined by the criterion of accumulated concentration, see reference [25] for details.

The retention capacity of building groups was about R = 15, calculated by Equation (8) based on a relative stable virus outdoor concentration distribution at t = 300 s. Small value of R would indicate the pollutant retention capacity of building layout was small and thus facilitate easy dispersion of the pollutants.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: By comparing with the previous experimental data, the predictions of air flow and the virus particle concentration by Lagrangian-Eulerian model were validated. The appropriate assumption of collision between the particles and wall was established. Numerical results have indicated that LES and Lagrangian-Eulerian model can fully capture the indoor and outdoor virus particle flow, especially the low Reynolds number flow near-wall. Results show that the high concentration of virus could spread far from the outbreak room with the vortex shedding, leading to a high risk of secondary infection in large areas. To control the spread of virus, the control of wind flow field would be the most effective way.

The exposure assessment was studied by applying the simulation results. The evaluation criteria presented here is very simple, comparing to the real situation and would provide a valid methodology for future exposure assessment and infection outbreak evaluation study.
